Hugo A. Rojas a ⁎ José J. Martínez a Gabriela Díaz b Antonio Gómez-Cortés b a Escuela de Ciencias Químicas, Universidad Pedagógica y Tecnológica de Colombia UPTC, Avenida Central del Norte, Vía Paipa, Tunja, Boyacá, Colombia Escuela de Ciencias Químicas Universidad Pedagógica y Tecnológica de Colombia UPTC Avenida Central del Norte Vía Paipa Tunja Boyacá Colombia b Instituto de Física, Universidad Nacional Autónoma de México, Circuito de la Investigación Científica s/n, Cd. Universitaria, México D.F. 04510, Mexico Instituto de Física Universidad Nacional Autónoma de México Circuito de la Investigación Científica s/n Cd. Universitaria México D.F. 04510 Mexico ⁎ Corresponding author. Graphical abstract The effect of gold addition to iridium catalysts and the nature of active sites for citral hydrogenation were investigated over Ir–Au/TiO2 catalysts. All samples (Au/TiO2, Ir/TiO2 and Ir–Au/TiO2) were prepared by deposition-precipitation with urea (DPU). Bimetallic catalysts were synthetized by co-deposition at different Ir/Au atomic ratios (3, 1, 0.3). The catalysts were characterized by ICP, BET, H2–TPR, H2-Chemisorption, TEM, DRIFTS and XPS techniques. A partial coverage of iridium sites by gold atoms takes place as the gold amount in the catalyst increases as shown by chemisorption and XPS measurements. The latter also evidenced a trend consistent with modification of the electronic environment of iridium due to interaction with gold atoms. Also, compared to Ir/TiO2, the amount of Irδ+ species was higher in the bimetallic catalysts reaching a maximum in Ir–Au (1) sample. Characterization of the catalytic surface using DRIFTS of adsorbed CO evidenced a shift towards higher wavenumbers as a function of the gold content indicating, as the XPS results, a modification of the adsorption site. The catalytic activity for citral hydrogenation increased as a function of the gold content. The selectivity to unsaturated alcohol is related to the amount of Irδ+ species which in turns depends on the catalyst composition. For the most active sample Ir–Au (1), a suitable Irδ+/Ir0 ratio is already obtained when the catalyst is reduced at 573K and does not vary with reduction temperature. Keywords Ir–Au TiO2 Citral Hydrogenation Irδ+/Ir0 ratio 1 Introduction Different approaches have been undertaken to increase the activity and selectivity towards unsaturated alcohols in the hydrogenation of unsaturated α, β aldehydes. Among them, bimetallic catalysts constituted of a platinum group metal and gold supported catalysts have shown to be very active and selective for the reduction of various α, β-unsaturated carbonyl aldehydes. For example, Pt entities dispersed over Au NPs supported on SiO2 (coded as Pt ^Au), showed a dramatic activity enhancement (up to 70-fold) for the chemoselective hydrogenation of cinnamaldehyde without changing the selectivity. A synergic effect between Pt and Au was proposed to explain this observation, in which the Pt sites activate the H2 molecules whereas the Au sites serve to activate the unsaturated substrate molecules by chemisorption [1,2]. Pd–Au catalysts supported on mesoporous silica nanoparticles promote the hydrogenation of cinnamaldehyde [3]. The activity of the bimetallic catalyst was up to four times higher than that of the monometallic Pd catalyst (without Au as promoter) and eight times higher than that of a commercial Pd/C catalyst. The effect of metal composition was investigated showing that alloy formation plays a key role in determining the structure of the PdAu catalyst and the significantly improved activity was ascribed to Pd high dispersion and modified electronic properties. Recently, Zhang et al., [4] demonstrated that Au atoms which can be controllably assembled at the top position on the surface of a mother cluster constituted by noble metal atoms, exhibit a high catalytic activity. Among bimetallic systems, Au–Ir surface alloys, have been investigated for its anomalous interactions with hydrogen [5]. Although hydrogen molecules almost spontaneously dissociate over ordinary transition metals (e.g., Ir [6]) a considerable activation barrier prevents hydrogen molecules from dissociating on single-crystal gold surfaces. However, Okada et al., [7] reported that Au thin films grown epitaxially on an Ir single crystal surface are able to dissociate H2. This feature can be contrasted to the well-known noble bulk Au surfaces, which do not dissociate hydrogen molecules. We have previously shown [8] that Ir–Au/TiO2 catalysts are more active and selective towards the unsaturated alcohol in the hydrogenation of citral than Ir/TiO2 or Au/TiO2. The effect of addition of gold to iridium catalysts was more evident in the case of samples reduced at 573K. It is likely that the iridium contributes to the dissociation of hydrogen and besides facilitates the preferential reduction of the carbonyl group. However, the nature of active sites not was totally clarified. The citral hydrogenation is a model reaction for catalytic tests in the field of selective hydrogenation of α, β-unsaturated carbonyl compounds [9]. In the present work, the liquid phase hydrogenation of citral was studied using Ir–Au/TiO2 catalysts with different bimetallic composition. The principal aim was to investigate the effect of gold content on the activity and selectivity of Ir catalysts, and to contribute to the knowledge of this type of bimetallic systems for hydrogenation reactions. 2 Materials and methods 2.1 Chemicals The support was TiO2 (Degussa P-25) with a specific surface area (S BET) of 50m2/g previously activated under vacuum at 423K. H2IrCl6 (Aldrich>99%), HAuCl4 (Aldrich>99%), citral (SigmaAldrich>98% (the E/Z isomer ratio of the citral substrate was 0,72 as verified by GC), heptane (J.T. Baker) were used without further purification. 2.2 Preparation of catalysts Ir/TiO2 and Au/TiO2 catalysts were prepared by deposition-precipitation using urea (DPU). Briefly, 1g of TiO2 was added to 100mL of an aqueous solution of HAuCl4 or H2IrCl6 (0.52×10−3 M) and urea (0.052M) under stirring in a rotavapor and heated at 353K for 16h. Afterwards the sample was washed with water, centrifuged and dried under vacuum at 373K. The nominal metal content was 1.0wt.%. Bimetallic samples were prepared by co-deposition at different atomic relations Ir/Au (3, 1, 0.3). The nominal total metal loading (Ir+Au) was kept at 1.0wt.%. The preparation protocol was similar to that described for monometallic catalysts including this time aqueous solutions containing both precursors. Identification of these samples is Ir–Au (3), Ir–Au (1) and Ir–Au (0.3). All samples, monometallic and bimetallic were calcined in air at 673K and finally reduced in hydrogen at 573K for 2h. 2.3 Characterization Elemental analysis was performed using induced coupled plasma (ICP) in an OPTIMA 21200 Perkin Elmer spectrometer to determine the actual Ir and Au contents. Textural properties of the solids were obtained by N2 adsorption–desorption isotherms measured at 77K in a Micromeritics ASAP 2020 equipment. Samples were previously evacuated at 623K for 16h. The BET method was used to calculate the total surface area of the samples. Metal dispersion of the catalysts was evaluated by H2-chemisorption at 308K using a pulse technique in a Micromeritics ASAP 2920 apparatus. Reduction properties were characterized by thermo-programed reduction (H2-TPR) in the same equipment using a 5% H2/Ar gas mixture flow (30mL/min) and a heating rate of 10K/min up to 1073K. Metal particle size was determined by transmission electron microscopy in a JEM 2010F analytical microscope equipped with HAADF detector. The reduced catalyst sample was dispersed in isopropanol using ultrasound for several minutes. Subsequently, a drop of the solution was placed on a holey carbon copper grid for observation. At least 150 particles were measured to obtain the particle size distribution and the average particle size d s defined as: d s = Σ n i d i 3 Σ n i d i 2 where n i represents the number of particles with a diameter d i. CO adsorption on the surface of the catalysts was studied by FTIR spectroscopy in a Nicolet Nexus 470 spectrophotometer equipped with an in-situ diffuse reflectance cell (Harrick, Praying Mantis) with KBr windows. Prior to CO adsorption, 0.01g of sample was reduced in-situ in H2 flow (30mL/min) at 573K for 1h. Following the reduction, the cell was purged with He flow (30mL/min) for 30min. The sample was cooled to room temperature in the same gas atmosphere and reference DRIFT spectra of the solid were collected. Then, the sample was put in contact with a 5% CO/He gas mixture (30mL/min) for 6min. The cell was purged again with He for 10min and a new spectrum was collected. Spectra were collected from 256 scans with a resolution of 4cm−1. In all cases, reported spectra take into account the spectrum of the freshly reduced solid prior to CO adsorption. Surface characterization of the samples was achieved by XPS in a Thermo Scientific Escalab 250 XI spectrometer. Measurements were performed at room temperature with monochromatic Al Kα radiation (hv = 1486.6eV). The analyzer was operated at 25eV pass energy and a step size 0.05eV. The pressure in the analytical chamber was 6.3×10−3 MPa. The signal of C 1s (284.6eV) was used as internal energy reference. Determination of core-level peak positions was accomplished after background subtraction using CasaXPS software. Peaks in a spectrum were fitted by a combination of Gaussian and Lorentzian curves, which also allowed separating overlapping peaks. The samples were reduced in-situ at 573K. 2.4 Catalytic studies Liquid phase hydrogenation reaction was carried out in a batch type reactor at a constant stirring rate (1000rpm) under the following conditions: hydrogen partial pressure of 0.62MPa, catalyst sample 200mg, 25mL of a 0.1M solution of citral in heptane and reaction temperature of 363K. Prior to the experiment, all catalysts were reduced at 573K and once loaded in the reactor were treated in situ in hydrogen flow of 20mL/min at atmospheric pressure at 363K. Reaction products were analyzed in a GC–MS Varian 3800 furnished with an β-Dex Column, He as carrier, and constant temperature of 393K. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Chemical composition and textural properties Table 1 displays the actual metal loading and the textural properties of the catalysts determined respectively by ICP and N2 adsorption. For monometallic catalysts results show that almost the nominal metal loading (1wt.%) has been deposited; 0.89wt.% for Au and 0.92wt.% for Ir. The actual total metal loading in the bimetallic samples was around 0.75wt.% which is lower than expected. Moreover, the nominal atomic Ir/Au ratio was not achieved; only in the case of Ir–Au (1) this parameter was near the nominal value, while for Ir–Au (3) a significant loss of Au is observed. As previously observed [10], when both Ir and Au are codeposited using DPU approach, the target loading of gold is not obtained. The textural properties of the TiO2 support were not modified by the presence of gold or iridium particles as can be observed from the results in Table 1. The nitrogen adsorption–desorption isotherms correspond to type IV in the BDDT classification showing a hysteresis loop typical of cylindrical pores. No significant change in the support surface area, neither in the average pore size, occurs after the deposition of the metallic components (Fig. 1 ). 3.2 Reduction properties Fig. 2 displays the temperature programmed reduction profiles (H2–TPR) of Ir–Au/TiO2 catalysts. For Au/TiO2 sample the reduction to metallic gold is characterized by one peak only around 373K [10]. Well defined reduction peaks at 357K and 469K along with and a smaller one at 392K were observed for Ir/TiO2. The reduction peaks in the TPR profile of iridium samples have been associated to the reduction of large and dispersed IrO2 particles [10–12]. On the other hand, the bimetallic catalysts Ir–Au (3) and Ir–Au (1), show a reduction profile similar to that displayed by Ir/TiO2 catalyst, although the relative intensity of the hydrogen peaks is dependent on the iridium content and the peak observed at 469K appears at lower temperatures. This fact suggests that the presence of gold in iridium catalysts facilitate the reduction of some of the iridium species present in the catalyst. For bimetallic Ir–Au/TiO2 catalysts with a metal composition Ir/Au=0.3 the TPR profile changes significantly showing that reduction peaks shift to higher temperatures. 3.3 Metal particle size distribution Fig. 3 displays typical images in Z-contrast mode (STEM) and the corresponding particle size distribution histograms for Ir–Au (3) and Ir–Au (1) catalysts reduced at 573K. As observed the particle size distribution changes as the gold content in the sample increases. The average particle size ds is 2nm. For Au–Ir/TiO2-Rutile sample with equimolar metal composition (Ir/Au=1), EDX determinations showed that composition of the metal particles was not homogeneous, some small particles around 1nm size were iridium only, while larger particles about 2–3nm in size were bimetallic Ir–Au [13]. Accordingly, not all metallic particles in our catalysts would be bimetallic. 3.4 Metal dispersion Table 2 tabulates the dispersion (DH/Ir) calculated from H2 chemisorption at 308K taking into account the Ir atoms only. Data are compared to particle size (ds) and geometrical metal dispersion (D TEM) estimated from TEM analysis. As observed, for Ir/TiO2 catalyst, particle size determined by TEM and H2-chemisorption was practically the same, but for Ir–Au/TiO2 catalysts this was not the case. For Ir–Au (3) and Ir–Au (1) catalysts, the H/Ir ratio showed decreasing values as the gold content increases. This result cannot be attributed to a decrease in the metal dispersion because no changes in the metal particle size were observed by TEM. This behavior is probably due to a partial coverage of the iridium sites by gold atoms leading to a surface decoration of the Ir crystals that depends on the gold content, in agreement with reported theoretical studies [14]. 3.5 Surface characterization DRIFT spectra of CO adsorbed at room temperature on the surface of catalysts reduced in-situ at 573K are shown in Fig. 4 . A broad band in the spectral range 1950 to 2150cm −1 is observed which indicates that CO is adsorbed on different type of iridium species. The Ir/TiO2 catalyst showed an intense absorption band with a strong maximum at 2073cm−1 characterizing CO adsorption on Ir0 sites [15,16] and a shoulder at c.a. 2005cm−1. On their side Au/TiO2 catalyst is characterized by a small band located around 2120cm−1 which characterizes linear adsorption of CO on metallic gold sites [17]. For bimetallic catalysts two features are observed as a function of the decreasing amount of iridium in the sample. First, the intensity of the band is lower compared to iridium monometallic catalyst, which could be explained as the result of less iridium adsorption sites which is supported by the H2 chemisorption measurements. Second, a progressive shift to higher wavenumbers takes place at least for Ir–Au (3) and Ir–Au (1) catalysts. This result points out to a modification of the electronic environment of the iridium adsorption sites due to interaction with gold atoms. For Ir–Au (0.3) catalyst, the position of the CO band shifts toward lower frequencies with a significant diminution of intensity. A decrease of CO coverage due to less iridium adsorption sites would explain both, the diminution of the intensity and the redshift as the coupling of adsorbed CO molecules decreases. Photoelectron spectroscopy was used to determine the chemical state of iridium and gold at the catalysts surface. Fig. 5 displays the XPS spectra collected in the region of Ir 4f core levels characterized by the two spin orbit components doublet, Ir 4f7/2 and Ir 4f5/2. In the same region appears a signal corresponding to Ti 3s. Decomposition of the spectra led to five contributions corresponding two of them to Ir 4f7/2, another two for Ir 4f5/2 and one for the Ti 3s level. In addition, XPS spectra were collected in the region of Au 4f core levels (not shown). In the following the reported values of binding energy (BE) will refer to Ir 4f7/2 and Au 4f7/2 core electrons. The binding energies (BE) of Ir 4f and Au 4f core levels and the Ir/(Ir+Au) surface atomic ratios are compiled in Table 3 . Two BE values were observed for Ir/TiO2 catalyst, one at 61.1eV and the other at 62.4eV. The first characterizes Ir0 atoms while the latter corresponds to partially oxidized Irδ+ species [18,19]. The relative contribution of these species showed that Ir0 is the main species. The binding energy of the Au 4 f7/2 core electrons in the Au/TiO2 catalyst is 83.9eV which is characteristic of Au0 [20]. For bimetallic Ir–Au/TiO2 catalysts the BE of iridium is observed at 61.2eV and 62.5eV, for respectively, Ir0 and Ir δ+ species. The relative amount of Irδ+ increased as a function of the gold content reaching a maximum for Ir–Au (1) catalyst. In the case of gold, a constant BE value of 83.8eV was observed. On the other hand, the atomic ratio Ir/Ir+Au decreases as the gold content in the catalyst increases which indicates that gold is progressively present in the catalyst surface. Although the observed shift in BE energy is rather small, there is a trend that points out to a modification of the electronic environment of both metals in the catalysts. This possibility would be in line with the results of CO adsorption followed by DRIFTS shown previously, where the position of the CO band characterizing adsorption on iridium sites shifts to higher frequencies. A Mulliken population analysis [21] performed on the most stable structures of the gas-phase clusters Au5Ir15, Au10Ir10 and Au15Ir5 [14] within the DFT-GGA framework provides a confirmation of electronic transfer between iridium and gold atoms. This analysis suggests that there is an electronic charge transfer from the iridium atoms to the gold ones, the values being respectively, 0.729, 1.182 and 0.693 in units of the electron charge. 3.6 Catalytic performance in citral hydrogenation Table 4 summarizes the reaction rate and selectivity results calculated at 10% conversion of citral. The rate was defined as mole of citral converted per second and mole of metal (Ir+Au) present in the catalyst. As observed, Ir/TiO2 catalyst is very active compared to Au/TiO2. The low activity of the gold catalyst could be related to the particle size and the low hydrogen dissociation on gold catalysts [22–24]. For bimetallic catalysts, the activity follows the order Ir–Au (1)>Ir–Au (3)>>Ir–Au (0.3). The highest activity is achieved for an atomic ratio Ir/Au=1. As previously shown, for this catalyst the highest amount of iridium non-reduced species were evidenced by XPS experiments; thus, development of Irδ+sites correlates with the increase in the catalytic activity. From the gold point of view, the addition of iridium as in Ir–Au (0.3), also increases the activity of the gold catalyst. An interesting fact that comes from inspection of selectivity data in Table 4 is that the selectivity of the reaction is controlled by the iridium species. The reaction network showing the main products is described in Fig. 6 . The Au/TiO2 catalyst presents a selectivity to saturated aldehydes, SC C ≈25% while for Ir/TiO2 it is 2%. In the case of Ir–Au/TiO2 catalysts SCC is lower than that of gold catalyst and more alike to that of iridium; for Ir–Au (3) and Ir–Au (1) it is≤2% and for Ir–Au (0.3) it is 10%. The presence of Irδ+ species favors the preferential hydrogenation of the carbonyl group. It has been widely reported that if the active phase is present essentially in a zero valent state (M0), the favored reaction is the hydrogenation of the CC bond in α, β unsaturated aldehydes leading to the saturated aldehyde. On the contrary, if the active sites at the catalyst surface are M0 with an important proportion of Mδ+ sites, the main products are unsaturated alcohols as the pathway shifts to the reduction of the carbonyl bond due to the contribution of these species to the polarization the CO bond making its hydrogenation easier [25,26]. In order to establish the influence of the reduction temperature on the activity of bimetallic Ir–Au/TiO2 catalysts, the Ir–Au (1) catalyst was reduced at temperatures from 573K to 773K and the conversion of citral followed as a function of reaction time, Fig. 7 . The reduction at progressively higher temperatures has no significant effect on the catalyst reactivity; it is only after 4h reaction, that the catalyst reduced at 773K was a little more active. It is clear that reduction of the bimetallic catalyst at temperatures higher than 573K does not have the same effect on the activity of the catalyst as it has in the case of Ir/TiO2 for which high temperature reduction leads to a significantly more active catalyst than that reduced at low temperature [27,28]. This result suggests that in the presence of gold, the Irδ+/Ir0 ratio which accounts for the increase in reactivity and selectivity for carbonyl hydrogenation is already obtained when the catalyst is reduced at 573K. It seems that it is possible to obtain a similar effect as that observed for Ir/TiO2 at the SMSI state, when Ir–Au/TiO2 is reduced at 573K. 4 Conclusions The effect of metal composition of Ir–Au/TiO2 catalysts on the activity and selectivity for the liquid phase hydrogenation of citral was investigated. Characterization by several techniques confirmed the close interaction of both metals in the samples. As a function of gold addition: (i) the TPR profile of iridium is modified; (ii) a progressive coverage of the iridium sites by gold atoms was evidenced by hydrogen chemisorption and XPS; (iii) although rather small, the observed shift in binding energy points out to a modification of the electronic environment of iridium due to interaction with gold atoms; (iv) the blue shift of the CO band when adsorbed over iridium sites evidenced by DRIFTS further confirmed this; (v) the highest catalytic activity is observed for sample with the highest amount of Irδ+ species, being Ir–Au(1) sample. Although the selectivity of the reaction is controlled by the iridium species, the presence of gold modifies the Irδ+/Ir0 ratio leading to high active and selective catalysts towards the unsaturated alcohol. coredata.dc:description: The effect of gold addition to iridium catalysts and the nature of active sites for citral hydrogenation were investigated over Ir–Au/TiO2 catalysts. All samples (Au/TiO2, Ir/TiO2 and Ir–Au/TiO2) were prepared by deposition-precipitation with urea (DPU). Bimetallic catalysts were synthetized by co-deposition at different Ir/Au atomic ratios (3, 1, 0.3). The catalysts were characterized by ICP, BET, H2–TPR, H2-Chemisorption, TEM, DRIFTS and XPS techniques. A partial coverage of iridium sites by gold atoms takes place as the gold amount in the catalyst increases as shown by chemisorption and XPS measurements. The latter also evidenced a trend consistent with modification of the electronic environment of iridium due to interaction with gold atoms. Also, compared to Ir/TiO2, the amount of Irδ+ species was higher in the bimetallic catalysts reaching a maximum in Ir–Au (1) sample. Characterization of the catalytic surface using DRIFTS of adsorbed CO evidenced a shift towards higher wavenumbers as a function of the gold content indicating, as the XPS results, a modification of the adsorption site. The catalytic activity for citral hydrogenation increased as a function of the gold content. The selectivity to unsaturated alcohol is related to the amount of Irδ+ species which in turns depends on the catalyst composition. For the most active sample Ir–Au (1), a suitable Irδ+/Ir0 ratio is already obtained when the catalyst is reduced at 573K and does not vary with reduction temperature.
coredata.dc:title: The effect of metal composition on the performance of Ir–Au/TiO2 catalysts for citral hydrogenation.
